script: Me and him was sheriffs at the same time, him up in Plano and me out here.
I think he's pretty proud of that.
Some of the old-time sheriffs never even wore a gun.
A lot of folks find that hard to believe.
Gaston Boykins wouldn't wear one up in Comanche County.
I always liked to hear about the old-timers.
Never missed a chance to do so.
You can't help but compare yourself against the old-timers can't help but wonder how they'd have operated these times.
There's this boy I sent to the electric chair at Huntsville here a while back.
Papers said it was a crime of passion, but he told me there wasn't any passion to it.
Told me he'd been planning to kill somebody for about as long as he could remember.
Said if they turned him out, he'd do it again.
Said he knew he was going to hell.
I don't know what to make of that.
The crime you see now, it's hard to even take its measure.
It's not that I'm afraid of it.
I always knew you had to be willing to die to even do this job.
But I don't want to push my chips forward and go out and meet something I don't understand.
A man would have to put his soul at hazard.
I'll be part of this world.
Yes, sir, I just walked in the door.
Sheriff, he had some sort of thing on him, like a oxygen tank for emphysema or something and a hose that run down his sleeve.
What the hell's he got that for?
Well, you can look at it when you get in.
I'll be down there in a bit.
Yes, sir, I got it under control.
Step out of the car, please, sir.
I need you to step out of the car, sir.
Would you hold still, please, sir?
I told you, I ain't got no agua.
I reckon I go out the way I come in.
But if you stop, you stopped in shade.
What'd you get for that thing?
Well, you don't need to know everything, Carla Jean.
Keep running that mouth of yours, I'm gonna take you in the back and screw you.
Fine. I don't want to know.
I don't even want to know where you been all day.
A little something I forgot to do, but I'll be back.
I'm fixing to do something dumber than hell, but I'm going anyways.
If I don't come back, you tell Mother I love her.
Well, then I'll tell her myself.
Y'all getting any rain up your way?
Well, I seen you was from Dallas.
What business is it of yours where I'm from, friendo?
Well, I didn't mean nothing by it.
I was just passing the time.
If you don't want to accept that, I don't know what else I can do for you.
Is that what you're asking me?
Is there something wrong with anything?
Well, I need to see about closing now.
You don't know what you're talking about, do you?
I said you don't know what you're talking about.
What time do you go to bed?
You're a bit deaf, aren't you?
I said, what time do you go to bed?
Why would you be coming back?
Well, I got to close now.
You live in that house out back?
You lived here all your life?
Well, this is my wife's father's place, originally.
We lived in Temple, Texas for many years.
Raised a family there, in Temple.
We come out here about four years ago.
If that's the way you want to put it.
Well, I don't have some way to put it.
What's the most you ever lost on a coin toss?
The most you ever lost on a coin toss.
I don't know. I couldn't say.
Well, we need to know what we're calling it for here.
I can't call it for you, or it wouldn't be fair.
You've been putting it up your whole life.
You know what date is on this coin?
It's been traveling 22 years to get here.
And it's either heads or tails.
And you have to say. Call it.
Well, look, I need to know what I stand to win.
Don't put it in your pocket, sir.
Don't put it in your pocket.
Where do you want me to put it?
Or it'll get mixed in with the others and become just a coin.
Why would we go to Odessa?
Look, right now it's midnight, Sunday.
The courthouse opens nine hours from now.
Someone's gonna be calling in the vehicle number on the inspection plate on my truck.
And around 9:30, they'll show up here.
But for how long do we have to...
Baby, at what point would you quit bothering to look for your $2 million?
What am I supposed to tell Mama?
Why don't you try standing in the door and hollering, Mama, I'm home?
Anything you leave, you ain't gonna see again.
Come on, I can't take them back.
I thought it was a car afire.
Wendell said there's something in the back country, too.
When's the county gonna start paying a rental on my horse?
I love you more and more every day.
Wouldn't think a car'd burn like that.
That look like about a '77 Ford to you, Wendell?
The old boy shot by the highway?
Man killed Lamar's deputy, took his car, killed that man on the highway, swapped for his car and now here it is, and he's swapped again for God knows what.
If anything happens to Loretta's horse out here, I can tell you right now, I don't want to be the party that was aboard.
It's the same tire tread coming back as going.
Made about the same time, too.
You can see the sipes real clear.
Somebody's pried the inspection plate off the door on this one.
Belongs to a feller named Moss.
Oh, hell's bells, they even shot the dog.
Well, this is just a deal gone wrong, isn't it?
Appears to have been a glitch or two.
What calibers you got there, Sheriff?
Somebody unloaded on that thing with a shotgun.
How come you reckon the coyotes ain't been at them?
Supposedly a coyote won't eat a Mexican.
These boys appear to be managerial.
I think we're looking at more than one fracas.
Oh, these boys is all swole up.
You know, might not even have been no money.
Well, it's a mess, ain't it, Sheriff?
If it ain't, it'll do till the mess gets here.
Did you go up too his trailer?
Well, I'd say he's at work.
Do you want to leave a message?
Sir, I ain't at liberty to give out no information about our residents.
We can't give out no information.
Why all the way to Del Rio?
I don't want to register it.
Look, I'll call you in a couple days.
I got a bad feeling, Llewelyn.
Well, I got a good one, so that ought to even out.
Listen, you gotta quit your worrying so much.
She's just gonna cuss you up and down.
Well, you should be used to that.
I'm used to lots of things.
You are coming back, ain't you?
I believe they done lit a shuck.
So, when was he here, Sheriff?
We gotta circulate this on radio.
Looking for a man who has recently drunk milk?
You think this boy Moss has got any notion of the sorts of sons-of-bitches that are hunting him?
I don't know. He ought to.
He's seen the same things I've seen, and it certainly made an impression on me.
You pick the option goes with the applicable rate.
I'm just one person, so it don't matter the size of the bed.
Now, why would I expect him?
Yeah, you got a pair of Larry Mahans, shoulder, size 11?
Well, white's all I wear. Bathroom?
Just ride me up past those rooms.
I wanna see if someone's here.
get into some kind of a jackpot here, buddy.
Why don't I just set you down right here and we won't argue about it?
Look, you're already in the jackpot, and I'm trying to get you out of it.
The lab reports from Austin on that blood by the highway.
Well, Wendell, with all due respect, that don't make a lot of sense.
You said entry wound in the forehead, no exit wound.
You telling me he shot this boy in the head and then went digging around in there with a pocket knife?
Well, sir, I don't wanna picture that.
Can I freshen that there for you, Sheriff?
Rangers and the DEA are headed back out to the scene this morning.
Any new bodies accumulate out there?
Well, then I guess I can skip it.
Yeah, that'll give you a wallop.
Well, you give me the model number on the tent, I can order you the poles.
No, ma'am, I wanna keep my room and get another one.
And do you have a map of the rooms?
Well, yeah, we had a sort of one.
Well, you can have the one right next to yours if you want, number 137.
Even a young man like you.
You know Anton Chigurh by sight, is that correct?
Yes, sir, I know him every which way.
When did you last see him?
Seem pretty sure of the date.
No, sir, but you struck me as a man who wouldn't wanna waste a chair.
We're out a bunch of money, and the other party is out his product.
This account will only give up $1,200 in any 24-hour period.
If your expenses run higher, I hope you'll trust us for it.
Just how well do you know Chigurh?
I just wanna know your opinion of him, in general.
Compared to what, the bubonic plague?
He's bad enough you called me.
Yeah, he's a psychopathic killer, but so what?
Killed three men in a Del Rio motel yesterday, and two others in that colossal goat fuck out in the desert.
You've led something of a charmed life, haven't you, Mr. Wells?
In all honesty, I can't say that charm has had a whole lot to do with it.
Could you validate my parking ticket?
An attempt at humor, I suppose?
Counted the floors to this building from the street.
Yes, sir, I'll be right here till 10:00 in the morning.
Now, I ain't asking you to do anything illegal.
There's someone who been looking for me.
You just call me if anyone else checks in tonight.
And by anyone, I mean any swinging dick.
Don't worry, I ain't gonna hurt you.
I need you to drive me on out of here.
Were you in a car accident?
I'll give you 500 bucks for that coat.
Were you in a car accident?
Any word on those vehicles yet?
Sheriff, I found out everything there was to find.
Those vehicles are titled and registered to deceased people.
The owner of that Bronco's been dead 20 years.
Do you want me to see what I can find out about the Mexican ones?
Gonna try to keep from it much as I can.
Wanted to know if you wanted to go with him.
Can I get you to call Loretta for me, tell her I'm going to Odessa to see Carla Jean Moss?
I'll call her when I get done.
I'd call her now, but if she want me to come home, I just might.
Do you want me to wait till you quit the building?
You don't wanna lie without what it's absolutely necessary.
What is it Torbert says about truth and justice?
Oh, we dedicate ourselves daily anew.
I'm gonna commence dedicating myself twice daily.
Might come to three times before it's over with.
You looked at your load lately?
How many bodies did you leave with?
I ain't lost none of 'em, Sheriff.
Couldn't y'all have taken a van out there?
We didn't have no van with four-wheel drive.
You gonna write me up for improperly secured load on me?
You get your ass out of here.
I'm guessing this isn't the future you had pictured for yourself when you first clapped eyes on that money.
Don't worry. I'm not the man who's after you.
What's this guy supposed to be, the ultimate badass?
I don't think that's how I'd describe him.
I guess I'd say he doesn't have a sense of humor.
You know how he found you?
Yeah, I know how he found me.
Any of it. If it can be welded, I can weld it.
So what does that make me, your buddy?
Look, you gotta give me this money.
I got no other reason to protect you.
About a million-and-a-half on whores and whisky, and the rest of it, I just sort of blew it in.
How do you know he's not on his way to Odessa?
Why would he go to Odessa?
Maybe he's the one who needs to be worried about me.
You're not cut out for this.
You're just a guy who happened to find those vehicles.
I'm across the river at the Hotel Eagle.
Call me when you've had enough.
I'm gonna even let you keep a little of the money.
If I was into cutting deals, why wouldn't I just deal with this guy Sugar?
You can't make a deal with him.
Even if you gave him the money back, he'd still kill you just for inconveniencing him.
Might even say he has principles.
Principles that transcend money or drugs or anything like that.
Yeah. He's not even like me.
No, he don't talk as much as you.
I give him points for that.
Carla Jean, thank you for coming.
I told you, I don't know where he is.
Would you tell me if you had?
He don't need any trouble from you.
It ain't me he's in trouble with.
Who's he in trouble with, then?
These people will kill him, Carla Jean. They won't quit.
You know Charlie Walser's got that place out east of Sanderson?
Well, you know how he used to slaughter beeves, hit 'em right there with a maul, truss 'em up and slit their throats?
You know, Charlie's got one all trussed up, all set to drain him, and the beef comes to, starts thrashing around.
Six hundred pounds of very pissed off livestock.
Charlie grabs a gun there, shoot the damn thing in the head, but with all the swinging and the thrashing, it's a glance shot.
Ricochets around, comes back, hits Charlie in the shoulder.
You go see Charlie, he still can't pick up his right hand for his hat.
The point being that even in the contest between man and steer, the issue is not certain.
When Llewelyn calls, just tell him I'd make him safe.
Course, they slaughter steers a lot different these days.
Shoots out a little rod about that far into the brain.
Why are you telling me that, Sheriff?
You don't have to do this.
Make it worth your while, take you to an ATM with 14 grand in it.
I know where the satchel is.
If you knew, you would have it with you.
I can find it from the river bank.
It will be brought to me, and placed at my feet.
You don't know to a certainty.
In 20 minutes it could be here.
I do know to a certainty.
And you know what's gonna happen now, Carson?
There would be more dignity in it.
If the rule you followed brought you to this, of what use was the rule?
Do you have any idea how crazy you are?
You mean the nature of this conversation?
I mean the nature of you.
You can have the money, Anton.
Not in the sense that you mean.
You need to come see me.
You need to talk to me.
I don't need to talk to you.
Do you know where I'm going?
Why would I care where you're going?
You're in the hospital across the river, but that's not where I'm going.
Do you know where I'm going?
Yeah, I know where you're going.
You know she won't be there.
It doesn't make any difference where she is.
So, what're you going up there for?
You know how this is gonna turn out, don't you?
So, this is what I'll offer.
You bring me the money and I'll let her go.
Otherwise, she's accountable, the same as you.
That's the best deal you're gonna get.
I won't tell you you can save yourself, because you can't.
Yeah, I'm gonna bring you something, all right.
I've decided to make you a special project of mine.
You ain't gonna have to come look for me at all.
None of the three had ID on them, but they're telling me that all three is Mexicans.
There's a question, whether they stopped being and when.
Now, Wendell, did you inquire about the lock cylinder?
Naw, that's all I had to look for, and it sound like these old boys died of natural causes.
Natural to the line of work they was in.
My God, Wendell, it's just all-out war.
I can't think of any other word for it.
Here, last week, they found this couple out in California.
They rent out rooms to old people, kill them, bury them in the yard, cash their Social Security checks.
Maybe their television set was broke.
Neighbors were alerted when a man ran from the premises wearing only a dog collar.
You can't make up such a thing as that.
But that's what it took, you notice, to get somebody's attention.
Digging graves in the backyard didn't bring any.
Ain't a whole lot else you can do.
Who do you think gets through this gate into the United States of America?
And if I get sensible answers, then they get to go to America.
And if I don't get sensible answers, they don't.
Anything about that you don't understand?
-Then I ask you again, how you come to be out here with no clothes?
Well, I got an overcoat on.
Get someone to help this man.
He needs to get into town.
You have a lot of people come in here without any clothes on?
She don't want to talk to you.
Yes, she does. Put her on.
Do you know what time it is?
I don't care what time it is, and don't you hang up this phone.
I don't know. I had the sheriff here from Terrell County.
What did I know to tell him?
I can hear it in your voice.
There is falseness in his voice.
Well, look, I want you to meet me at the Desert Sands Motel in El Paso.
Because I'm gonna give you the money, I'm gonna put you on a plane.
Llewelyn, I ain't gonna leave you in the lurch.
With you gone and I don't have the money, he can't touch me, but I can sure touch him.
And after I find him, I'll come and join you.
What am I supposed to do with mother?
He gave the Mexicans a receiver.
He felt that the more people looking...
You pick the one right tool.
Are you going to shoot me?
I always seen this is what it'd come to.
Three years ago, I pre-visioned it.
It ain't even three years we been married.
Three years ago I said them very words. No and good.
Here we are, 90 degree heat, I got the cancer and look at this, not even my home to go to.
We're going to El Paso, Texas.
You know how many people I know in El Paso, Texas?
Well, I put it in that one.
I'll get tickets and a cart for the bags.
You need help with the bags, madam?
Well, thank God, there is one gentleman left in west Texas.
Going to El Paso, don't ask me why.
It's not often you see a Mexican in a suit.
You go to El Paso? I know it.
Sheriff, was that a true story about Charlie Walser?
True story. I couldn't swear to every detail, but it's certainly true it is a story.
Sheriff, can you give me your word on something?
If I tell you where Llewelyn's headed, you promise it'll be just you who goes and talks with him?
Llewelyn would never ask for help.
He never thinks he needs any.
Carla Jean, I will not harm your man.
And he needs help, whether he knows it or not.
Hey, what's the problem there, neighbor?
Yep, that'll suck some power, over time.
Just lighting out for the territories, huh?
If you want someplace specific, you might could be better off just driving to Dallas, not have to connect.
Can you get those chicken crates out of the bed?
I got beers in my room.
Oh, I'm waiting on my wife.
Oh. That's who you keep looking out the window for?
Yeah. But no one ever sees that.
I'll bring the ice chest out here. You can stay married.
No, ma'am, I know what beer leads to.
Buy you a cup of coffee before you drive home?
No money in his room there?
Those hombres would have taken the stash.
Though they was leaving in a hurry.
It's all the goddamn money, Ed Tom.
You know, if you'd have told me 20 years ago that I'd see children walking the streets of our Texas towns with green hair, bones in their noses, I just flat-out wouldn't have believed you.
But I think once you quit hearing sir and ma'am, the rest is soon to follow.
It is not the one thing.
Yeah, well, none of that explains your man, though.
He's just a goddamn homicidal lunatic, Ed Tom.
I'm not sure he's a lunatic.
Yeah, well, what would you call him?
Well, sometimes, I think he's pretty much a ghost.
Yeah. All of that over at the Eagle Hotel?
Yeah. Got some hard bark on him.
Why, well, that don't hardly say it.
He shoots a desk clerk one day, walks right back in the next and shoots a retired army colonel.
Just strolls right back into a crime scene.
Now, who'd do such a thing?
How do you defend against it?
Sorry we couldn't help your boy.
How'd you know I was here?
Who else'd be driving up in your truck?
I seen one of the cats heard it.
How'd you know it was my truck?
I deduced it when you walked in.
How many of them things you got now?
Cats? Oh, I don't know, several.
Well, it depends on what you mean by got.
Some of them are half wild, some of them are just outlaws.
I got to say, you're looking older.
Got a letter from your wife.
She writes me pretty regular, keeps me up on the family news.
I generally make a fresh pot every week, even if there's some left over.
That man that shot you died in prison?
What'd you done, he'd have been released?
Wouldn't be no point in it.
Kindly surprised to hear you say that.
Well, all the time you spend trying to get back what's been took from you, more is going out the door.
After a while, you just have to try to get a tourniquet on it.
Your granddad never asked me to sign on as a deputy.
I always figured when I got older, God would sort of come into my life somehow.
If I was him, I'd have the same opinion of me that he does.
You don't know whatt he thinks.
I sent Uncle Mac's thumb buster and badge over to the Rangers, put it in their museum.
Your daddy ever tell you how Uncle Mac come to his reward?
Gunned down on his own porch over in Hudspeth County.
Seven or eight of them come up there, all wanting this, wanting that.
Uncle Mac went back in the house to get the shotgun, well, they was ahead of him.
Aunt Ella come out, tried to stop the bleeding.
Uncle Mac all the while trying to get that shotgun.
They just sat there on their horses, watching him die.
After a while one of them said something in Indian and they turned, left out.
Uncle Mac knew the score, even if Aunt Ella didn't.
And that was that, as they say.
No, I mean, was it right away, or in the night or...
I believe it was that night.
She buried him the next morning.
Digging in that hard old caliche.
What you got ain't nothing new.
This country is hard on people.
It ain't all waiting on you.
I knew this wasn't done with.
What little I had is long gone and there's bills aplenty to pay yet.
You got no cause to hurt me.
No. But I gave my word.
You gave your word to my husband to kill me?
Your husband had the opportunity to save you.
Instead he used you to try to save himself.
You don't have to do this.
People always say the same thing.
They say, You don't have to do this.
This is the best I can do.
I knowed you was crazy when I saw you sitting there.
I knowed exactly what was in store for me.
The coin don't have no say.
Well, I got here the same way the coin did.
Mister, you got a bone sticking out of your arm.
I'm all right. Let me just sit here a minute.
The man over yonder went to call.
You got a bone sticking out your arm.
What'll you take for the shirt?
Well, hell, mister, I'll give you my shirt.
Just tie it, just tie it.
Look, I don't mind helping someone out.
Take it and you didn't see me.
You know part of that's mine, right?
You still got your damn shirt.
Ain't even what it was for.
Well, maybe. But I'm still out a shirt.
Well, I can't plan your day.
I mean, would you care to join me?
Maybe I'll help out here, then.
Well, you got time for them now.
They always is to the party concerned.
All right, then. Two of them, both had my father in them.
I'm older now than he ever was by 20 years.
So, in a sense, he's the younger man.
Anyway, the first one I don't remember too well, but it was about meeting him in town somewheres and he give me some money.
The second one, it was like we was both back in older times and I was a-horseback going through the mountains of a night.
Going through this pass in the mountains.
It was cold and there was snow on the ground.
And he would... Rode past me and kept on going.
Never said nothing going by, just rode on past.
He had his blanket wrapped around him and his head down.
When he rode past, I seen he was carrying fire in a horn, the way people used to do, and I could see the horn from the light inside of it, about the color of the moon.
And in the dream, I knew that he was going on ahead.
And he was fixing to make a fire somewhere out there in all that dark and all that cold.
And I knew that whenever I got there, he'd be there.
